election_record.label: Massachusetts 1804 Governor

overview.note: "BY THE MAILS. PORTLAND, MAY 24. The District of Maine Republicanized. We have taken considerable pains in selecting from the Returns received, those Lists of Votes for Governor, (in Maine District,) which appeared to be most correct ... Thus the citizens of this growing country are fast returning to those principles which effected our glorious Revolution, and will no longer be ranked 'high in Federal politics.'" The Salem Register (Salem, MA). May 28, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Barnstable
sub_unit.note: James Sullivan received 6 votes as Judge Sullivan.

sub_unit.name: Chatham
sub_unit.note: James Sullivan received 13 votes as James Sullervin.

sub_unit.name: Berkshire
sub_unit.note: "General Election.--On Monday last the annual Election for State Officers took place. Our readers will see, by the following return of Votes for Governor, that the county of Berkshire remains firm in Republican principles. An increasing majority is highly honorary to the cause of republicanism; while a consumptive decline of federalism forebodes its dissolution. In spite of the pitiful arts of delusive federalism, several large and opulent towns in this county have, in this election, arranged themselves on the side of the principles of LIBERTY. Lanesborough, which 'till now, has been guided for many years by the counsels of anti-revolutionary and anti-republican men, has turned her back on tory doctrines, and espoused the whig principles of our country. We anticipate she will not again be found fighting in the ranks of the enemies of our general government. Stockbridge too, the head-quarters of federalism in this county, has stricken the federal standard--And in Richmond, federalism has been weighed in the scales and found wanting." The Pittsfield Sun (Pittsfield, MA). April 9, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Hancock
sub_unit.note: James Sullivan received 34 votes as James Sullovent.

sub_unit.name: Cumberland
sub_unit.note: "CORRESPONDENCE.--TO THE EDITOR. From Portland.--'The democrats, with Wedgery at their head, held a secret caucus here, to cram down the democratic list.--This getting wind, a meeting of the federalists was called; which was full and spirited.--Mr. Parker addressed the citizens in a judicious and animating speech; and the result was the largest federal vote ever given in this federal town.'" The Columbian Centinel and Massachusetts Federalist (Boston, MA). April 7, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Essex
sub_unit.note: "The above three towns [Newbury, Newburyport, Salisbury] give a larger federal majority than we had anticipated, considering the unwearied exertions of the democrats. Last year Newburyport gave 417 Newbury 229 and Salisbury 50, for Gov. STRONG." Newburyport Herald (Newburyport, MA). April 3, 1804.

"The Antifederalists have spared no pains to turn the vote of Essex County in their favour. We are happy that the above statement of the votes proves they have not succeeded. ... We have not thought it necessary to detail the votes for Governor. Mr. STRONG will be re-elected by a large majority.--It is remarkable that even in his own town the votes were more than two to one against Mr. SULLIVAN. The Antis will try him a few years, and then throw him by as they have Mr. Gerry." The Salem Register (Salem, MA). April 5, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Lynn
sub_unit.note: "From Lynn.--'Republicanism has again triumphed over the ignis fatuous or mock sun of federalism in this place.' " The Salem Register (Salem, MA). April 5, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Springfield
sub_unit.note: Edward H. Robbins received 1 vote as Ebenezer H. Robbins.

sub_unit.name: Hancock
sub_unit.note: "From Castine, April 8, 1804. TO THE EDITOR. 'I do myself the pleasure to inclose you a list of the votes from the several towns from which I have heard since the annual meeting for the choice of General Officers. This is for a sample--I verily believe that every town in the county of Hancock has given as large majorities for Sullivan and Heath as those I enclose to you. If the other counties have done as well as we have done, the jig is up with the Junto.'" The Salem Register (Salem, MA). April 16, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Eden
sub_unit.note: Elbridge Gerry received 1 vote as Albridge Gerry.

sub_unit.name: Athens
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Athen.

sub_unit.name: Maddison
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Maddison.

sub_unit.name: Monmouth
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Monmouth.

sub_unit.name: Rome
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Rome.

sub_unit.name: Bristol
sub_unit.note: James Sullivan received 133 votes as James Sulivhan.

sub_unit.name: Middlesex
sub_unit.note: The Official Returns list Caleb Strong with 2179 votes in Middlesex County but the town totals add up to 2171.

sub_unit.name: Roxbury
sub_unit.note: Edward H. Robbins received 2 votes as Edward Robbins.

sub_unit.name: Bolton
sub_unit.note: Edward H. Robbins received 1 vote as Edward Robbins.

sub_unit.name: Alfred
sub_unit.note: Caleb Strong received 25 votes as Cabel Strong.

sub_unit.name: Phillipsburgh
sub_unit.note: James Sullivan received 94 votes as James Sulivan.
